FCT and VAT implications
Overview of Vietnamese taxation
Foreign Contractor Tax (“FCT”) is a comprehensive tax collection regime that applies to, amongst others, foreign business organizations, with or without permanent establishment (“PE”) in Vietnam, doing business in Vietnam or having Vietnam-sourced income on the basis of a contract, agreement or undertaking with Vietnamese organizations. Broadly, FCT is a collection mechanism for Corporate Income Tax (“CIT”) and Value Add Tax (“VAT”).
Conceptually, FCT will not be applied if the goods are supplied with the place of delivery at the border gates, and without accompanied services provided in Vietnam.

XYZ, via VC3, will subscribe for new shares in JVCo 1 / 2 at a premium, at a total of USD 7.2 million which represents a 99.8% stake in JV Co 1 / 2. VC3 will have 2 wholly owned SPVs that will own nominal (0.1%) stake in JV Co 1 / 2.
VC3 will then provide shareholder loans of USD 22.5 million to JV Co 1 / 2.
JV Co 1 / 2 will use the total proceeds of USD 29.7 million to acquire 100% shares in TH 1 / 2
ABC will then subscribe to new shares of JV Co 1 / 2 for a total consideration of USD 22.5 million (comprising USD 1 million of chartered capital and USD 21.5 million of share premium). JV Co 1 / 2 will use the proceeds received to repay the USD 22.5 million shareholder loan to VC 3.

In the case of transferring capital previously contributed to establish the enterprise, the historical cost is the actual capital amount which has been cumulatively contributed by the capital assignor (the investor) as at the assignment date. This original value of the assigned capital must be supported by and based on accounting books, invoices and vouchers; in addition, it must be certified by investors or participants in the business cooperation contract, or according to audit results provided by an independent audit company if the enterprise is a 100% Foreign Invested Enterprise.

Of note, regarding the underlined part above, it is unclear whether the audited financial statements (“FS”) can also be used if the enterprise is not 100% foreign invested (which is the case of JVCo1 and JVCo2). Nevertheless, in practice, the audited FS is normally used in this case together with the payment evidences of capital contribution, and we have not seen any challenge from local tax authorities on such arrangement.

Upon future divestment of ABC1 and ABC2 from JVCo1 and JVCo2 (which we assume are non-public joint stock companies at that time), where ABC1 and ABC 2 will be subject to 20% CAT in Vietnam on the gain (which is calculated as transfer price minus capital cost), there is a risk that the capital cost may be challenged by the Vietnam tax authorities.

Based on another private ruling which was not made public issued by Ho Chi Minh City Tax Department dated 29 January 2021, Investor 1 (Singapore) invested in Investee (Vietnam) with premium. The premium was shared to Investor 2 (BVI), and Investor 2 duly paid tax in Vietnam. Subsequently, Investor 2 contributed such money back into capital contribution in the Investee. The ruling stated that the capital cost when Investor 2 disposes its investment would include such premium value.

In case of sale/transfer of the assets, JVC is required to declare and pay Value Added Tax (“VAT”) (at the rate of from 5% or 10% depending on the type of assets sold/transferred) and Corporate Income Tax (“CIT”) (at the standard rate of 20%) on the revenue/taxable income generated from the sale/transfer of assets (if any) in accordance with the prevailing laws.

Fulfilling tax liabilities and deactivating JVC’s tax code

JVC is required to conduct the following procedure to deactivate the company’s tax code for the purpose of terminating its operations:

Notification on the deactivation of the tax code: JVC shall submit to the tax authority a dossier for deactivation of its tax code which comprises document requesting deactivation of tax code and a copy of the dissolution resolution.

Within two (2) working days from receipt of required documents for the dissolution of the Company, the tax authority shall issue a written Notification acknowledging that the Company has ceased its operations and is conducting the procedure for deactivating its tax code.

Preparing and submitting the VAT declaration returns

JVC shall submit its VAT declaration returns to the local tax authority till the last periods of its operation. 

Same as CIT matters as aforementioned, JVC should make all supporting documents related to its input VAT available before the dissolution date to avoid risk of input VAT being treated non-creditable.

Tax audit: When receiving of the sufficient tax finalisation dossiers from JVC, the tax authority is responsible to carry out the procedure for tax audit at the JVC’s premises for the purpose of dissolution of JVC and deactivation of the tax code of JVC. In practice, the actual timing for tax audit depends on the working schedule of the local tax authority and delay is always anticipated in this procedure.

If there is a gain, such gain would be subject to Capital Assignment Tax (“CAT”) at the rate of 20%. Please refer to Appendix 1 for more information on Vietnam CAT. 

The transfer of capital in JVC by J-SPC is not subject to VAT and registration fee in Vietnam.

Nguyen Thanh Tam
Managing Director, Tax services

Selling an interest by a foreign investor in a company established under Vietnam Enterprise Law and/or Investment Law to another investor (i.e., capital assignee) in Vietnam is deemed as a direct investment transfer and subject to Circular 78 and Circular 96. In this regard, the capital assignor who earns income (or technically should be known as making gains) from assignment of capital is subject to a Corporate Income Tax (“CIT”) rate of 20% on any gain derived from the capital assignment. This tax on capital assignment is generally referred to as CAT.

Background
ABC Co., Ltd (“the Company”) was incorporated in Vietnam under the Enterprise Registration Certificate (“ERC”) No. xxx dated 28 May 2008 issued by the Business Registration Office of Vinh Phuc Department of Planning and Investment and licensed to carry out the project under Investment Registration Certificate (“IRC”) No. xxx dated 28 May 2008 issued by the Management Board of Vinh Phuc Industrial Zones (the “Original Investment Project” or “OIP”).
The OIP’s objectives include (a) manufacturing and selling automotive components and parts for automobiles and motorcycles, and (b) trading raw materials, machines and tools for manufacturing automotive components and parts for automobiles and motorcycles. 
Activity (a) is entitled to Corporate Income Tax (“CIT”) at the preferential rate of 15% in 12 years from the first year it operates (FY08), CIT exemption for 03 years from the first year it generates a taxable profit (FY09-11) and 50% CIT reduction for the 07 succeeding years (FY12-18). That said, no CIT incentive is available for OIP after FY18. 
The Company applied for the 5th amended IRC dated 1 August 2022 for the increase in the investment capital and the charter capital, changes in project’s objectives and increase in production capacity (the “Expansion Investment Project” or “EIP”).
The changes in the project’s objectives include (i) removal of “Trading automotive components and parts for automobiles and motorcycle; Trading raw materials for manufacturing automotive components and parts for automobiles and motorcycles”; and (ii) supplementation of “Exercising the right to import, export, wholesale distribution (without setting up the wholesale outlet), products include: indicators, license plate lights, 4-wheel ceiling lights”.
The increase in investment capital, charter capital and production capacity is summarised as follows:
Per the Company’s confirmation, the increased investment capital is for construction of a new factory (Factory 2), new machinery and technology for manufacturing components and parts for motorcycles. The budgeted value for the EIP is estimated at VND87,707,515,448 with detailed break-down below. On the above background, the Company is considering whether it can avail the possible CIT incentive applicable to the EIP under the current Vietnamese tax regulations.

Tax exemption
Under the current Vietnamese tax regulations, where Vietnam enters into a DTA with a contracting country, provisions agreed under the DTA will prevail in cases where differences exist between the domestic laws and the DTA. For the contemplated capital transfer, Vietnam – Singapore DTA and Vietnam – the UK DTA and might be referred to respectively.
Possibility for tax exemption under Vietnam – Singapore DTA
Pursuant to Paragraph 4, Article 13 (Capital gains) of Vietnam – Singapore DTA which was amended by Article VII, Announcement No. 05/2013/TB-LPQT:
“Gains derived by a resident of a Contracting State from the alienation of shares, other than shares of a company posted on a recognized stock exchange of one or both Contracting States, deriving more than 50% of their value directly or indirectly from immovable property situated in the other Contracting State may be taxed in that other State.”
That said, under Vietnam - Singapore DTA, as THE VIETNAMESE COMPANY’s shares are not posted on a recognized stock exchange of both Vietnam and Singapore, gain from capital transfer will be taxed in Vietnam if THE VIETNAMESE COMPANY’s assets consist, directly or indirectly, more than 50% of immovable property situated in Vietnam (i.e. the ratio of immovable property).
Regarding the calculation of the ratio of immovable properties of THE VIETNAMESE COMPANY:
In accordance with Point 4, Article 27, Circular 205/2013/TT-BTC dated 24 December 2013 of Ministry of Finance, providing the guidance on the DTA implementation regarding the capital transfer:
“Ratio of immovable property value in total properties of enterprise is simple average of ratios of immovable property value in total properties of enterprise at time of transfer of property, the beginning time and ending time of tax year prior to year when the shares are transferred. Determination of immovable property value is based on the audited summary of properties of enterprise at the aforesaid times.
The principal ratio of immovable property value in total properties of enterprise is determined as follows: “… Where Agreement specifies the rate or principal rate, complying with the rate prescribed in Agreement”.
We hereafter present our approach to determine the value of immovable property as follows:
Pursuant to Clause 2, Article 6 of the Vietnam – Singapore DTA, the term "immovable property" shall have the meaning which it has under the law of the Contracting State in which the property in question is situated.
Pursuant to Circular 205, in the case of Vietnam, immovable property includes:
Types of assets as stipulated under definition of immovable property of Civil Code and Law on Real Estate Trading;
Sub-assets attached to these aforementioned assets;
Livestock and equipment used in agriculture and forestry;
Rights applied under law on land in Vietnam; 
Rights to enjoy payments for the natural resource exploitation or the right to exploit natural resources.
